The Act may be cited as the "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2014" and the table of contents is provided. The "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2014" includes provisions for improved newborn and child screening for heritable disorders, evaluation of screening programs, establishment of advisory committees, and authorization of appropriations for research programs. The "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2014" has been amended to provide education in newborn screening, counseling, and training for health care professionals and laboratory personnel on relevant technologies, timeliness of specimen collection, and sharing medical information. The "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2014" has been amended to improve the timeliness of specimen collection, diagnosis of heritable disorders in newborns, and sharing medical information with providers and families. SEC. 3. EVALUATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF NEWBORN AND CHILD SCREENING AND FOLLOWUP PROGRAMS. Amends Section 1110 of the Public Health Service Act to include evaluation of screening and follow-up programs for newborns and children, emphasizing timeliness and effectiveness. The amendment includes improving quality in diagnosis, treatment, and disease management of heritable disorders and achieving timely methods for eligible entities described in section 1109. The amendment aims to improve the quality of diagnosis, treatment, and disease management of heritable disorders in newborns and children. It includes achieving timely methods for eligible entities as described in section 1109, such as collection, delivery, receipt, and screening of newborn screening specimens, and diagnosis of heritable disorders in newborns. Additionally, it involves amendments to the Public Health Service Act to provide technical assistance for the submission of nominations to the uniform screening panel. The amendment aims to improve the quality of diagnosis, treatment, and disease management of heritable disorders in newborns and children by preparing for the review of nominations, including cost and incidence information, to achieve best practices in rapid diagnosis and appropriate treatment. The amendment focuses on improving the timeliness of specimen collection and testing for heritable disorders in newborns to ensure rapid diagnosis and follow-up. It also includes changes in timelines for decision-making by the Secretary. The amendment aims to improve the timeliness of specimen collection and testing for heritable disorders in newborns. It includes changes in timelines for decision-making by the Secretary, such as notifying the Advisory Committee and Congress of delays in compliance and setting deadlines for review of nominated conditions. The Advisory Committee will meet at least 4 times a year and continue operating through the end of fiscal year 2019, with the possibility of extension if not reauthorized. SEC. 5. CLEARINGHOUSE OF NEWBORN SCREENING INFORMATION. Section 1112 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to maintain current information on the number of conditions for newborn screening. SEC. 6. LABORATORY QUALITY AND SURVEILLANCE. SEC. 6 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include "laboratory quality and surveillance." This involves changes in subsection (a) regarding newborn-screening tests and the expertise of the Advisory Committee. Subsection (b) is updated to focus on surveillance activities conducted by the Secretary through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include coordination of surveillance activities for newborn screening. This involves standardized data collection, electronic health records, and promoting data sharing with State-based monitoring programs. Additionally, an Interagency Coordinating Committee on Newborn and Child Screening is established under section 1114. SEC. 8. NATIONAL CONTINGENCY PLAN FOR NEWBORN SCREENING.
    Section 1115(a) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to update the plan as needed and at least every five years.
SEC. 9. HUNTER KELLY RESEARCH PROGRAM.
    Section 1116 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to restructure subparagraphs and enhance research efforts. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Part A of title XI of the Public Health Service Act is amended to authorize appropriations for newborn screening programs and activities. SEC. 1117 authorizes appropriations for newborn screening programs and activities, allocating $11.9 million for sections 1109, 1110, 1111, and 1112, and $8 million for section 1113 for fiscal years 2015 through 2019. Additionally, SEC. 11 mandates a GAO report on the timeliness of newborn screening within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The report submitted under paragraph (1) shall include an analysis of newborn screening timeliness, guidelines for supporting timely screening, barriers to maintaining a timely system, and recommendations for addressing those barriers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit a report to specific committees on newborn screening and screening for heritable disorders, with updates every two years. The report must detail ongoing activities and expenditures related to these screenings under certain sections of the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 12. INFORMED CONSENT FOR NEWBORN SCREENING RESEARCH: Research on newborn dried blood spots for Federally funded research must adhere to human subject research regulations until updates are made. This applies to blood spots collected within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Regulations must be updated within 6 months. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must update regulations related to informed consent under the Common Rule within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with final regulations to be issued within 2 years.
